title: How to Put Down a Hangi

steps.title: Gather volcanic stones for the hangi.
steps.content: Gather volcanic stones for the hangi. A hangi for 25 people will require enough volcanic stones to fill a 1 m (3.3 ft) in diameter hole, around 0.5 m (1.6 ft) deep. Non-volcanic stones will crack and explode when heated, which can be dangerous. Use a search engine to find where you can collect volcanic rocks in your area.

steps.title: Collect pieces of hardwood for the hangi.
steps.content: Collect pieces of hardwood for the hangi. Wood for a hangi must be untreated, and you will need 45 pieces that are 1 m (3.3 ft) long and 5-8 cm (2-3 in) wide. A slow burning wood such as mānuka or macrocarpa works well. A hangi will only be successful if the wood used takes a long time to burn, which is why hardwoods are necessary.

steps.title: Get 3 food baskets.
steps.content: Get 3 food baskets. Food baskets for hangi are usually wire trays with sides, but they can be made out of a variety of different materials. Baskets that are made from small chicken mesh, or welded perforated steel containers are common. The number of baskets that you will need will depend on how many people you are feeding. Three baskets will be enough for 25 people. Typically the food is divided into the three baskets, one of red meat, the next poultry, and the last for vegetables.

steps.title: Dig the hole slightly bigger that the stacked food baskets.
steps.content: Dig the hole slightly bigger that the stacked food baskets. 200-300mm (7.9-11.8 in) deeper and 200mm (7.9 in) wider and longer than the baskets works well. The hole will need to be slightly larger than the food baskets when they are stacked, so that there is enough room for sacks to be placed on the sides which will protect the food from the embers and dirt. [1] X Research source A hole that’s too deep or big will make it difficult to retrieve the food safely when it’s ready. [2] X Research source Overall the hole will be big enough to hold the food baskets, sacks, and stones.

steps.title: Pile the wood and volcanic stones on the ground to make a fire stack.
steps.content: Pile the wood and volcanic stones on the ground to make a fire stack. There is no particular order to stack the wood and stones, and all that matters is that there is enough room beneath the stack to start a fire, and that the stones are evenly distributed throughout the stack. The fire stack should be located next to the pit, so that you can easily transfer the hot stones. [3] X Research source If you stack the wood and stones the day before you plan to have the hangi, make sure that you cover the stack with a tarpaulin overnight to prevent it getting wet.

steps.title: Light the wood in the fire stack in 3-4 places.
steps.content: Light the wood in the fire stack in 3-4 places. Light a match and set alight 3-4 corners of the fire stack. If the wood doesn't show flames immediately, blow gently on the smouldering area to help it along. [4] X Research source The fire will spread throughout the stack of wood and stones.

steps.title: Let the fire burn for 3-5 hours before you start cooking.
steps.content: Let the fire burn for 3-5 hours before you start cooking. This lets the stones gather enough heat to be able to eventually cook the food. You will know that the stones are ready to use when they are visibly white. [5] X Research source While the fire is burning, make sure that somebody is watching it at all times. This will ensure the safety of everyone, and someone can also make sure that the stones are placed back into the fire if they fall out. Watch out for a changing wind direction, as this could blow the stack over. If the stones are particularly large and are having trouble heating evenly, rotate them during this process. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Peel and cut the vegetables while the fire is burning.
steps.content: Peel and cut the vegetables while the fire is burning. Peel the potatoes, carrots, and kumara, and then chop them into pieces around 13 cm (5 in) in length, or the size of your palm. Aim to have 1 potato, 1 carrot, and 1 kumara per person. [7] X Research source Pieces that are too big won’t cook properly, but pieces that are too small will turn mushy. [8] X Research source If you want to add a seasoning to your hangi, sprinkle some garlic powder or dried herbs generously over the vegetables.

steps.title: Get the meat for the hangi.
steps.content: Get the meat for the hangi. Common meats that are used are pork, chicken, and lamb. Aim for around 400g (0.88 lb) of meat per person. Make sure that all frozen meats are fully thawed. [9] X Research source You can use many types of meat for a hangi. Chicken thighs or whole chickens are commonly cooked, and you can also use whole roast sized pieces of other types of meat. As long as the pieces aren't tiny and won't cook too fast, they will be fine inside the hangi. [10] X Research source You can season your meat at this stage if you prefer. Generous salt and pepper sprinklings are common, but garlic with herbs like rosemary and sage are also common. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Line the food baskets with foil or banana leaves.
steps.content: Line the food baskets with foil or banana leaves. Place a thin layer on the bottom of the food baskets, which will help to protect the vegetables and meat from the dirt. Modern hangi is generally lined with tin foil, but for a more traditional approach try cabbage or banana leaves. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Place the meat and vegetables in the lined food baskets.
steps.content: Place the meat and vegetables in the lined food baskets. Usually separate baskets are used for meat and vegetables, but you can put them together if you wish. Place the meat and vegetables pieces into the food baskets, with a single layer in each. [13] X Research source Using only a single layer in each will help the food to cook thoroughly.

steps.title: Use long shovels to transport the hot rocks from the fire into the hangi.
steps.content: Use long shovels to transport the hot rocks from the fire into the hangi. When the volcanic stones have turned white, move them carefully to the base of the hangi pit. Remove any remaining leftover wood pieces before you put the rocks into the pit. Place the stones side by side in the pit, with as few gaps between the stones as possible. [14] X Research source This part of the hangi process needs to be done as quickly as possible to prevent the rocks from cooling. Rotate people for transporting the rocks as it is a tiring process.

steps.title: Soak 5 sacks and 1 sheet of material in water.
steps.content: Soak 5 sacks and 1 sheet of material in water. Do this while the rocks are being moved from the fire and into the pit. Make sure that the sacks are thoroughly wet. This will help to create the steam that is necessary for the hangi to cook. Mutton cloth, a table cloth, or a bed sheet are ideal types of material to use for the sheet. The size and material of the sacks doesn't matter. As long as you have enough sacks to cover the stacked food baskets, then this is all that matters. Make sure that the sheet and sacks that you use are clean.

steps.title: Slap the hot rocks with the wet sacks gently a few times.
steps.content: Slap the hot rocks with the wet sacks gently a few times. This will help to create steam for the hangi. Make sure not to leave the wet sacks on the hot rocks for too long, as only momentarily is best. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Put the food baskets on the hot rocks.
steps.content: Put the food baskets on the hot rocks. Place the red meat and poultry in the pit first, closest to the rocks. Then place the vegetable basket on last, so that it is closest to the surface. [16] X Research source This order is necessary because the meat requires being closer to the heat than the vegetables.

steps.title: Place a wet sheet of material over the food baskets.
steps.content: Place a wet sheet of material over the food baskets. Make sure that the sheet is wide enough to fully cover the stack of food baskets. The sheet needs to drape far enough down to cover the bottom basket almost fully, but without touching the hot rocks. [17] X Research source Make sure that the sheet is still wet and hasn’t dried before you had a chance to put it on the food baskets. Soak it again if necessary.

steps.title: Cover the food baskets and wet sheet with the wet sacks.
steps.content: Cover the food baskets and wet sheet with the wet sacks. Place the wet sacks over the food, making sure that as much of the area is covered as possible. Make sure that the first sack covers the very top of the food, as this will be the last one that is removed. Then place the rest of the sacks covering the sides of the baskets until all of the food is protected from the dirt. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Cover the pit with dirt.
steps.content: Cover the pit with dirt. Start covering the pit from the edges, and work your way evenly over the food baskets.When the pit is fully covered, gently smooth down the dirt on top of the hangi. If any steam is released through the top, place more dirt on this area to prevent the steam from being released. [19] X Research source This will ensure that the dirt doesn’t cave in onto the food.

steps.title: Scrape the dirt off slowly after 3 hours.
steps.content: Scrape the dirt off slowly after 3 hours. Use a spade to carefully scrape the dirt off the top of the hangi. Continue this until you see the sacks. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Peel the sacks off the hangi.
steps.content: Peel the sacks off the hangi. Start with the outermost sack, and remove each layer until you reach the initial sack. Although the sacks will be hot, you will be able to remove them with your bare hands. [21] X Research source When removing the final few sacks, be careful not to let any dirt fall onto the food.

steps.title: Remove the 3 baskets of food.
steps.content: Remove the 3 baskets of food. Two people are required for each basket, as it will be very heavy and warm. Use gloves or towels to lift the hangi basket out, and carry it away from the dirt to a table to serve. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Take the food out of the baskets and serve it.
steps.content: Take the food out of the baskets and serve it. Carve out the meat into slices or portions. Serve the different types of meat on a plate with a few pieces of the vegetables.
